Award.AbstractNarration:
This project brings together US and Japanese networking researchers in a 1.5-day workshop to identify key challenges in enabling Trustworthy Networking for Smart and Connected Communities. The two focus areas of the proposed workshop are: (i) trustworthy optical networking, and (ii) trustworthy computing/networking platforms (e.g., IoT/CPS, edge cloud). Optical networks are necessary in the core of provider and enterprise networks as data rates increase, while IoT/CPS/edge clouds are expected to dominate future access networks. Funds requested for this workshop will be used to cover workshop expenses and travel costs for only US attendees.

The goals of the workshop are to identify key challenges in the focus areas of trustworthy optical networking and trustworthy computing/networking platforms for IoT/CPS and edge clouds. Specific attributes of trustworthiness include reliability, dependability, resilience, survivability and robustness. Attendees will make presentations, participate in breakout sessions to identify key challenges, and then collaborate on a workshop report. The expected outcomes include: (i) A list of key research challenges in the two focus areas of the workshop; (ii) An improved mutual understanding of research interests, research contributions, and testbeds in the two countries; (iii) An improved understanding of processes used in the two countries to enable mutually beneficial collaborations; (iv) Seeding of individual linkages; (v) An identification of research objectives and projects that are missing in one of the two countries with the goal of increasing awareness of unaddressed challenges; and (v) Workshop report.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to bring together US and Japan researchers, with expertise in the fields of optical networking, Internet of Things (IoT), Cyber­Physical Systems (CPS), and edge cloud computing, to a workshop. The goals of the workshop were to (a) identify key challenges (b) initiate the building of relationships between researchers from the two countries, and (c) exchange information on existing and/or planned experimental and simulation testbeds and research projects in the US and Japan. 


The workshop accomplished these goals and led to several cross-country collaborations, and proposal submissions to an NSF program called Japan-US Network Opportunity 2 (JUNO2)  R&D for Trustworthy Networking for Smart and Connected Communities. Awards were made for this program. The UVA team collaborated with Japanese researchers at Keio University and University of Electro-Communications, Japan, and the University of Texas at Dallas and submitted a proposal.


The workshop report was completed and posted on the workshop website https://pages.shanti.virginia.edu/JUTrustNet2016/files/2017/02/JUTrustNetWorkshopMar2016Report.pdf.

Other outcomes include (i) joint publications between our UVA team and researchers at Keio University and University of Electro-Communications, Japan, (ii) student trips to Japan and other conferences on IoT and trustworthy networking, (iii) student trips to meet with organizations such as Silicon Harlem, New York, and The Enterprise Center, Chattanooga, TN, interested in technology that was developed as a result of our cross-country collaborations, (iv) hosting of external researchers at UVA to meet with our researchers and students, and (v) sponsoring other US researchers to travel to Japan for their collaborations.
